entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French fresch, freis, of Germanic origin; akin to Old High German frisc fresh; akin to Old English fersc fresh

def.dt: :having its original qualities unimpaired: as
:full of or renewed in vigor :refreshed rose fresh from a good night's sleep
:not stale, sour, or decayed fresh bread
:not faded the lessons remain fresh in her memory
:not worn or rumpled a fresh white shirt
:not altered by processing fresh vegetables
:not salt
:free from taint :pure fresh air
:moderately strong
:experienced, made, or received newly or anew form fresh friendships
:additional another a fresh start
:original vivid a fresh portrayal
:lacking experience :raw
:newly or just come or arrived fresh from school
:having the milk flow recently established a fresh cow
def.set: probably by folk etymology from German frech
def.dt: :disposed to take liberties :impudent don't get fresh with me
:fashionable cool
:just recently :newly we're fresh out of eggs
:an increased flow or rush (as of water) :freshet
:a stream, spring, or pool of freshwater
:wind having a speed of 19 to 24 miles per hour (30 to 39 kilometers per hour) see beaufort scale table
:wind having a speed of 39 to 46 miles per hour (62 to 74 kilometers per hour) see beaufort scale table

entry.et: Middle English breth, from Old English brǣth; akin to Old High German brādam breath, and perhaps to Old English beorma yeast barm

def.dt: :air filled with a fragrance or odor
:a slight indication :suggestion the faintest breath of scandal
:the faculty of breathing recovering his breath after the race
:an act of breathing fought to the last breath
:opportunity or time to breathe :respite
:a slight breeze
:air inhaled and exhaled in breathing bad breath
:something (as moisture on a cold surface) produced by breath or breathing
:inhalation
:a spoken sound :utterance
:spirit animation
:a welcome or refreshing change
:almost simultaneously
:breathing very rapidly (as from strenuous exercise)
:so as to be barely audible mumbled something under his breath
